natural problem: A license plate consists of two letters followed by two digits; for example, $MP78$. Neither the digits nor the letters may be repeated, and neither the letter $O$ nor the digit $0$ may be used. When reading from left to right, the letters must be in alphabetical order and the digits must be in increasing order. How many different license plate combinations are possible?
natural solution: Given any set of two distinct letters (neither of which is O) and two distinct digits (neither of which is 0), we can build exactly one license plate because, whatever the letters and digits, there is only one allowed order.
We can choose two distinct letters (excluding O) in $\binom{25}{2}$ ways and two distinct digits (excluding 0) in $\binom{9}{2}$ ways.
Thus the total number of license plates is $\binom{25}{2}\binom{9}{2} = \boxed{10800}$.

shows  "combinations = 10800"

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes license_plates :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "license_plates = {n. \<exists>l1 l2 d1 d2. n = encode (l1, l2, d1, d2) \<and> l1 < l2 \<and> d1 < d2 \<and> valid_chars l1 l2 d1 d2}"
and h1 : "encode = (\<lambda>(l1, l2, d1, d2). mapping_function l1 l2 d1 d2)"
and h2 : "valid_chars = (\<lambda>l1 l2 d1 d2. l1 \<noteq> l2 \<and> d1 \<noteq> d2 \<and> l1 \<noteq> 'O' \<and> l2 \<noteq> 'O' \<and> d1 \<noteq> '0' \<and> d2 \<noteq> '0')"
shows  "card license_plates = 10800"

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = card {LP :: (char \<times> char \<times> nat \<times> nat). 
                      (\<forall> (A1, A2, D1, D2) \<in> {LP}. 
                      A1 \<noteq> A2 \<and> D1 \<noteq> D2 \<and>

 Thus the total number of license plates is $\binom{25}{2}\binom{9}{2} = \boxed{10800}$.
 *)

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes license_plate :: "string"
assumes h0 : "length license_plate = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i < j \<and> i < 2 \<and> j < 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i < nth license_plate j"
and h2 : "\<forall>i j. i < j \<and> i \<ge> 2 \<and> j \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i < nth license_plate j"
and h3 : "distinct (take 2 license_plate)"
and h4 : "distinct (drop 2 license_plate)"
and h5 : "\<forall>i. i < 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i \<in> set (['A'..<char_of(79)] @ [char_of(80)]<..<'Z')"
and h6 : "\<forall>i. i \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i \<in> set (['1'..'9'] - ['0'])"
shows  "card {license_plate. \<forall>i j. (i < j \<and> i < 2 \<and> j < 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i < nth license_plate j) \<and>
          (i < j \<and> i \<ge> 2 \<and> j \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i < nth license_plate j) \<and>
          distinct (take 2 license_plate) \<and> distinct (drop 2 license_plate) \<and>
          (\<forall>i. i < 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i \<in> set (['A'..<char_of(79)] @ [char_of(80)]<..<'Z')) \<and>
          (\<forall>i. i \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i \<in> set (['1'..'9'] - ['0']))} = 10800"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A license plate consists of two letters followed by two digits; for example, $MP78$. Neither the digits nor the letters may be repeated, and neither the letter $O$ nor the digit $0$ may be used. When reading from left to right, the letters must be in alphabetical order and the digits must be in increasing order. How many different license plate combinations are possible? The final Answer is 10800
 ### Proof
 Given any set of two distinct letters (neither of which is O) and two distinct digits (neither of which is 0), we can build exactly one license plate because, whatever the letters and digits, there is only one allowed order.
 We can choose two distinct letters (excluding O) in $\binom{25}{2}$ ways and two distinct digits (excluding 0) in $\binom{9}{2}$ ways.
 Thus the total number of license plates is $\binom{25}{2}\binom{9}{2} = \boxed{10800}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes license_plate :: "string"
assumes h0 : "length license_plate = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i < j \<and> i < 2 \<and> j < 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i < nth license_plate j"
and h2 : "\<forall>i j. i < j \<and> i \<ge> 2 \<and> j \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i < nth license_plate j"
and h3 : "distinct (take 2 license_plate)"
and h4 : "distinct (drop 2 license_plate)"
and h5 : "\<forall>i. i < 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i \<in> set (['A'..<char_of(79)] @ [char_of(80)]<..<'Z')"
and h6 : "\<forall>i. i \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i \<in> set (['1'..'9'] - ['0'])"
shows  "card {license_plate. \<forall>i j. (i < j \<and> i < 2 \<and> j < 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i < nth license_plate j) \<and>
          (i < j \<and> i \<ge> 2 \<and> j \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i < nth license_plate j) \<and>
          distinct (take 2 license_plate) \<and> distinct (drop 2 license_plate) \<and>
          (\<forall>i. i < 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i \<in> set (['A'..<char_of(79)] @ [char_of(80)]<..<'Z')) \<and>
          (\<forall>i. i \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> nth license_plate i \<in> set (['1'..'9'] - ['0']))} = 10800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
A four-character license plate has the following properties:

1. The first two characters are distinct letters, and they are in alphabetical order.
2. The last two characters are distinct digits, and they are in ascending order.
3. The first two characters are in the range 'A' to 'Y' (inclusive), with the exception of 'O'.
4. The last two characters are in the range '1' to '9' (inclusive), with the exception of '0'.

How many such license plates can be formed? The final answer is 10,800.
